user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of response_completed_callback:
```c
static void
response_completed_callback (void *cls,
                             struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             void **req_cls,
                             enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct UploadContext *uc = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == uc)
    return; /* this request wasn't an upload request */
  if (NULL != uc->pp)
  {
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (uc->pp);
    uc->pp = NULL;
  }
  if (-1 != uc->fd)
  {
    (void) close (uc->fd);
    if (NULL != uc->filename)
    {
      fprintf (stderr,
               "Upload of file `%s' failed (incomplete or aborted), removing file.\n",
               uc->filename);
      (void) unlink (uc->filename);
    }
  }
  if (NULL != uc->filename)
    free (uc->filename);
  free (uc);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in this function are compile-time invariant. The function contains only if statements whose controlling expressions depend on runtime values: (NULL == uc) depends on *req_cls, (NULL != uc->pp) depends on uc->pp, ( -1 != uc->fd) depends on uc->fd, and (NULL != uc->filename) depends on uc->filename. None of these are integer constant expressions or otherwise manifestly constant at compile time, so they do not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. There are no loops with invariant controlling expressions (no while/for/do-while constructs), and the permitted exceptions (infinite loops or the do-while constant-false case) are not applicable. Therefore there are no code fragments that require further investigation for Rule 14.3.
